Award.AwardTitle: Elucidate Chromatin Folding at the Mesoscale

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells orchestrate many essential biological processes around their genome, such as retrieval of genetic information for protein synthesis, DNA duplication for propagation, and DNA repair for damage remediation. However, it remains an open question what roles the genome itself plays in such fundamental DNA-directed processes. One critical barrier to answering this question is the lack of quantitative knowledge of how chromatin, the material form of the genome that consists of a complex assembly of nucleic acid and protein, is organized in three dimensional space and how the chromatin organization changes in response to various biological, chemical and physical factors in the cellular environment. This project will develop and use state-of-the-art experimental techniques combined with extensive data-driven computational modeling, with the goal to reconstruct three dimensional structures of chromatin. Through systematic studies of model chromatin systems in wide-ranging solution conditions, this project further aims to elucidate the governing principles of chromatin organization. Along with the research effort, this project will enrich educational experiences for broadly represented student groups, particularly in response to the current challenge of engaging and retaining students in STEM education. Specific emphasis will be placed on incorporating underrepresented groups in research and educational activities.

The objective of this project is to gain systematic, mechanistic understandings of the conformation and dynamics of chromatin modulated by solution conditions, genetic and epigenetic variations, and chromatin-architectural proteins. Folding of chromatin from its open structure of 'beads-on-a-string' is an intricate process that has challenged researchers for decades, in part due to the complex set of governing physical and biochemical factors, and in part due to the lack of experimental approaches at the pertinent length scales above the mono-nucleosome level (i.e., one to tens of nanometers). This project addresses both challenges by applying solution small angle x-ray and neutron scattering (SAXS/SANS) to the biochemically defined system of recombinant nucleosome arrays. The use of strong positioning DNA sequences yields regularly spaced and stable arrays of nucleosomes, and SAXS/SANS measures the distribution of inter-nucleosome mesoscale distances as the array folds. SAXS/SANS further has unique advantages of probing array native structures directly in solution and decomposing protein and DNA components via contrast variation. Significant efforts will be directed towards applying and developing data-driven computational modeling methods to reconstruct the three dimensional structures of nucleosome arrays. To dissect the multifactorial determinants of folding, arrays of increasing lengths (2, 3, 4, 6, and 12 nucleosomes) will be analyzed under relevant conditions of ions, molecular crowding, linker DNAs, histone variations, and chromatin architectural proteins. Completion of this project is expected to elucidate detailed mesoscale structures of nucleosome arrays in solution and the molecular mechanisms of chromatin folding, and to shed light on the genetics/epigenetics-structure-function relationship of chromatin in vivo. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project titled "elucidating chromatin folding at the mesoscale", carried out by a team of interdisciplinary researchers at the department of physics of the George Washington University (GWU), attains its scientific and educational objectives through research efforts focused on chromatin biophysics. Chromatin is the material form of genetic information. However, 60% of chromatin is made up of a broad class of proteins acting to package the rest 40% (i.e., gene) and regulate genetic activities such as turning on or off a certain gene. With chromatin carrying the eventual instruction code of biological processes, it is fundamental to our knowledge as to how chromatin is packaged and regulated. This GWU project aims to reconstruct three-dimensional structures of model chromatin and elucidate the underlying molecular interactions.

We identified a critical gap in our knowledge of chromatin structure at the nanometer length scale (i.e., mesoscale) and demonstrated that such mesoscale structure information can be successfully obtained from solution small-angle x-ray scattering (SAXS). Specifically,  chromatin can be viewed as "beads-on-a-string" at the mesoscale, and SAXS provides the distance-distribution between the beads. Our proof-of-principle measurements showed that such inter-bead distance distributions can be accurately determined with SAXS. In addition, we developed a computational tool to reconstruct three-dimensional chromatin structures based on the inter-bead distance distributions from SAXS measurements. Our computer algorithm combines Monte Carlo sampling of the "string" conformational spaces and Molecular Dynamics energy minimization to obtain realistic structure models of chromatin. It has been integrated into the SAXS calculation and ensemble modeling platform SASSIE for public use. In sum, this line of study establishes SAXS as a powerful method for studying chromatin mesoscale structures and makes available a computational tool for building chromatin structures.  

Why chromatin takes on a given structure is ultimately determined by the physical interactions between its constituents. We have taken a divide-and-conquer approach to measure the physical forces between chromatin "parts". For the "beads-on-a-string"-like chromatin to fold, inter-bead interactions are necessary. Each bead has both gene (DNA) and protein (histone) components, and we focused on how DNA-DNA interactions are modulated by the tails of histones and solution conditions. Histone tails are interesting and important as they are flexible and can stretch out from the main body to contact neighboring beads. The tails also carry opposite charges to DNA and are expected to strongly interact with DNA. In an effort to gain a comprehensive view of DNA-histone tail interactions, we have surveyed 30 9-residue-long tail segments taken from six types of major histones. We found that, when more than 3 out of the 9 residues are charged, DNA-DNA attraction is induced, signifying a legitimate driving force to chromatin folding. The more charged the residues are, the stronger the DNA-DNA attraction becomes as expected. Detailed analyses further revealed the importance of residue type, position, and modification for DNA-histone tail interactions, shedding light on the richness and complexity of the governing forces of chromatin folding. Meanwhile, we observed a surprising DNA sequence specificity that DNA-DNA attraction can be induced solely through its sequence. This raises new possibilities for the active participation of DNA in its own packaging and regulation. Taken together, our quantitative measurements of the physical forces in chromatin enable new mechanistic insights on the governing factors of chromatin folding and guide future experimental and computational studies.

The major educational objective of the project is to engage and retain students in STEM education through direct research participation and active student-faculty interactions. In each year of the project, a team of four to eight students, with educational backgrounds ranging from high school to Ph.D. candidacy, actively participated in our research undertaking under the direct supervision of the principal investigator (PI). For many, this was their first hands-on research experience in a lab and they often came back next year, giving a total of 20 student-years over the entire project period. The student researchers' efforts have resulted in four undergraduate theses and one Ph.D. dissertation, and all graduated students have gone for further STEM education or taken up STEM jobs. Moreover, the PI has been serving as an advisor to physics and biophysics majors, and this project enabled us to further enrich the outreach activities of our society of physics students (SPS), notably the construction of a magnetic levitation track. All these have contributed to the creation of an active cohort of students and faculty in the physics department.
